item.paragraph: (CTA Head) Reason For Exam: AAA and iliac stenosis

paragraph.content:
Name: Sandra Andrew HINKLE
mrn:T640432606
fin:A2144766210
accession no:92aT335517563
Sex: Male DOB: 1969-12-05 Age: 52 years
Study Date/Time: 2022-05-21 7:30 AM
Study Description: CTA Head
Attending Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Ordering Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Referring Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Primary Care Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
40215
INDICATION:
Carotid arterial stenosis. Prior right carotid artery stenting.
TECHNIQUE:
CT angiogram of the head and neck with contrast. 3-D reformatted images were acquired.
Evaluation for a significant carotid arterial stenosis is based on the NASCET
criteria. Radiation dose reduction techniques included automated exposure control or
exposure modulation based on body size.
COMPARISON:
Carotid duplex Doppler 2022-05-08. CT angiogram 2021-10-09
FINDINGS:
CTA neck: There is a three-vessel aortic arch. There is a focal stenosis of the
proximal left common carotid artery estimated 70%. There is diffuse atherosclerotic
disease throughout the left common carotid artery with maximal stenosis of 84%. The
stenosis associated with the left carotid bifurcation is dilated at 59%. The mid to
distal left internal carotid artery is widely patent. There is a right common carotid
artery/internal carotid artery stent. No evidence of an in-stent stenosis. Common
carotid and internal carotid arteries are patent.
Calcifications at the left vertebral artery origin are noted. There is suggestion of a
proximal left vertebral artery stenosis, however, calcification scan overestimate the
degree of stenosis. Distal left vertebral artery is occluded at the level of C1. The
right vertebral artery is patent. There is atherosclerotic calcifications at the
origin of the right vertebral artery, however no significant stenosis is evident.
CTA head: There is extensive atherosclerotic disease of the intracranial internal
carotid arteries with mild to moderate stenosis of the vessels. No aneurysm or
thrombosis. The middle cerebral arteries and anterior cerebral arteries are widely
patent. The anterior communicating arteries not clearly identified. The left posterior
communicating artery is patent. The right posterior communicating artery is not
identified.
The left vertebral artery is occluded at the skull base. Left vertebral artery is
reconstituted via the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. There is diffuse
atherosclerotic disease in the distal right vertebral artery. The basilar artery and
the posterior cerebral arteries are widely patent.
No dural venous thrombus.
IMPRESSION:
1. Extensive long segment atherosclerotic disease of the left common carotid artery
with a focal stenosis of the origin at the aortic arch. The long segment stenosis
measures up to 84% within the common carotid artery. Stenosis of the left carotid
bifurcation measures 59%.
2. Suspected stenosis of the proximal left vertebral artery, however, coarse
calcifications at the origin may overestimate the degree of perceived stenosis. The
distal left vertebral artery is occluded at the skull base with reconstitution of the
intracranial vertebral artery via the PICA branch.
3. Extensive atherosclerotic disease of the intracranial internal carotid arteries,
however, they are patent.
4. Severe atherosclerotic disease of the intracranial right vertebral artery.
Dictated by:Ryan Currier, MD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-05-21 12:15 PM
Signed by: Ryan Currier, MD
Signed DT/TM: 2022-05-21 12:24 PM
Editor: DT/TM:

***** Final *****
Dictated by: CURRIER, RYAN P, MD-RAD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-05-21 12:15 pm

Signed DT/TM: 2022-05-21 12:24 pm

item.paragraph: (CTA Abdomen Pelvis) Reason For Exam: AAA and iliac stenosis;AAA and iliac stenosis

paragraph.content:
Name: Sandra Andrew HINKLE
mrn:T640432606
fin:A2144766210
accession no:92qa821924257
Sex: Male DOB: 1969-12-05 Age: 52 years
Study Date/Time: 2022-05-21 7:00 AM
Study Description: CTA Abdomen Pelvis
Attending Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Ordering Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Referring Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
Primary Care Physician: APRN-FAM Andrew
40215
INDICATION:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm. Iliac artery stenosis.
TECHNIQUE:
CT angiogram of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast. 3-D reformatted images were
acquired. Radiation dose reduction techniques included automated exposure control or
exposure modulation based on body size.
COMPARISON:
None available.
FINDINGS:
AORTA: A fusiform dominant aortic aneurysm measures 4.4 cm. The aneurysm arises
approximately 4 cm below the left renal artery. Aneurysm length measures 6.5 cm. The
aorta tapers to normal caliber at the aortic bifurcation (1.8 cm).
There is a 75% stenosis of the proximal celiac artery. There is atherosclerotic
disease at the superior mesenteric artery origin, however no stenosis. There is a
greater than 70% stenosis of the proximal left renal artery. Atherosclerotic disease
is noted at the right renal artery, however no focal stenosis. The proximal IMA is
occluded with proximal reconstitution via collaterals (marginal artery of Drummond).
Dense atherosclerotic disease is noted at the common iliac arteries. There is a
greater than 50% stenosis of the proximal left common iliac artery. There is a greater
than 50% stenosis of the mid right external iliac artery. Diffuse atherosclerotic
disease is noted in the external iliac arteries and the common femoral arteries,
however no focal stenosis. The left internal iliac artery is occluded. There is
diffuse atherosclerotic disease of the right internal iliac artery.
ABDOMEN: There is emphysema in the lung bases. Early arterial phase imaging of the
solid abdominal organs are within normal limits. There is mild asymmetric atrophy of
the left kidney relation to the right kidney. The gallbladder is not distended. The
bowel is not dilated. The appendix is normal.
No pelvic mass. No enlarged pelvic or inguinal lymph nodes. Small bilateral inguinal
hernias are identified.
IMPRESSION:
1. 4.4 cm fusiform aneurysm of the infrarenal abdominal aorta.
2. Greater than 70% stenosis of the proximal celiac artery and the left renal artery.
Occluded proximal inferior mesenteric artery with reconstitution of the proximal
vessel.
3. Focal stenosis of the left common iliac artery and right common iliac artery.
4. Mild asymmetric atrophy of the left kidney is likely secondary to the renal
arterial stenosis.
Dictated by:Ryan Currier, MD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-05-21 9:39 AM
Signed by: Ryan Currier, MD
Signed DT/TM: 2022-05-21 9:49 AM
Editor: DT/TM:

***** Final *****
Dictated by: CURRIER, RYAN P, MD-RAD
Dictated DT/TM: 2022-05-21 9:39 am
Interpreted and electronically signed by: CURRIER, RYAN P, MD-RAD
Signed DT/TM: 2022-05-21 9:49 am
